ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned Intro Python and about political data. I also was able to get a summer internship in political data using the skills I learned.
I learned more about python, and how to code as it relates to the analysis of political campaign data.
Introduction to python using Pandas; in-depth coverage of methods of polling, building likely voter models, etc

I learned about python and data science on political campaigns. I would say I roughly learned 3 things 1) What data do political campaigns have access to? 2) What do campaigns do with  data to help them win? 3) Some discussion of whether data science actually helps campaigns win. Additionally, we got practice doing basic examples of real political data science using python, specifically the pandas and matplotlib libraries. We also discussed the ethics of some kinds of political data science, and talked to real-world practitioners who both informed us and taught us a bit about the controversies within the field at the moment.
Practice with basic statistical computing in Python. Basics of political model making.

Python (pandas), writing about political data, data wrangling, data analysis, data interpretation, data visualizations, building and assessing models, tackling a research question using data, reading articles that use data or visualizations critically (did they do anything to a graph to make it seem like something it is not? is it causation or correlation? are they exaggerating or downplaying stuff?)
Python code
Better understanding of political campaigns and how they operate, using python

How political campaigns use data science to their advantage, how to code in Python, the logic and math behind randomized experiments, and how to measure the effectiveness of an experimental variable, amongst other topics.

I learned an aspect of politics that is underrated. We learned about the factors that go behind a campaign and the technicalities that need to be considered when analyzing outcomes and decisions. It was a nice mixture of coding and qualitative assessment.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Kalla is really a cool guy to learn political data from. He's really accomplished but also super accessible via office hours. Weekly psets that take around 1-8 hours depending on the week.
I can't think of any weaknesses in this course! I think it was really well taught -- the professor was very clear and always returned assignments in a very timely manner.

Strength - class was very efficient, professor was very accessible
Weaknesses - no weaknesses

I honestly really enjoyed this course. Lecture was quite easy to follow and interesting, the P-Sets were challenging but not unbelievably so, and the final project is a great way to do some data science of your own and investigate a question you find interesting. Professor Kalla is also a really good lecturer, and is genuinely engaged with students and interested in their learning. My only caveat is that I don't feel like I have a great understanding of python or pandas once finishing the course (although the course has helped a lot). If you want to learn about python, then I would recommend taking additional courses (before or after).

strengths: Professor Kalla is really accomodating and cares about your well being, psets are quite easy and very little time consuming if you've taken other data science courses that are coding heavy before, you get to start the lab in class so you have less homework, class is very practical and one can easily see how you can apply these skills in an entry level political data job/internship, not a time intensive class at all, workload is not bad at all and exams are okay if you study decently

weaknesses: i wasnt too engaged in the lecture/discussion parts of the class sometimes
Not rigorous enough, not enough direction on coding

Strengths: lectures, homeworks were helpful to learning, Kalla is great. 
Weaknesses: we never spent class time on learning python. We were using a different package than the original YData course so it felt almost new, but we had to learn via google and stack overflow and self-teach the coding aspects of the course.

Manageable psets, challenging but doable tests, good lectures. Wish the difficulty of psets had ramped up more towards the end of the semester, and that material was presented in more interesting way.

Strengths: Nice size class, attentive professor, balance between political science and data science, great powerpoint from the professor,  very flexible and accommodating, great organization of problem sets
Weakness: Could review code a little more

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: NA
Posting the lectures ahead of time online was very helpful for virtual engagement
Labs, very accessible office hours, live seminars that were engaging.
The readings helped prepare for the next class. The breakout rooms also allowed us to speak more freely and get to know each other

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would, especially if you are an EPE / SDS major. It's kind of a gut but intellectually stimulating and rigorous at the same time. Probably my favorite class of all time.
Yes! This course is great.

Yes! Even you aren't interesting in pursuing a career in politics, this class is super interesting and informative! Professor Kalla is also amazing. I definitely feel like I learned a lot of coding from this class compared to other S&DS courses.

If you are interested in data science or political campaigns, then I would absolutely 100% recommend it. Even if you never code again, it is just very useful and interesting to understand what campaigns are actually doing with data science, if anything so you can parse out which media stories and popular beliefs about campaigns are probably false. It's a great class because it's both a nice intro to some basic python coding and a really good way to learn about campaign data. Professor Kalla is also a great lecturer and a really nice guy, and the workload is quite manageable. If you're interested in the material, then no reason not to take it.

Yes if you want to learn some applicable python skills in a low to medium work setting depending on your experience coding. the goal of the class is to land you an internship in some entry level job at a data science political firm so if that sounds like you, and you want a lot of practical skills in a class that is not too hard then definitely take it.
Yes! Kalla is a great prof and the course is really interesting.

Yes! In this data-driven age, it's interesting - and also scary - to see how political campaigns have adapted to this new climate. Additionally, learning how to code and analyze data are practical skills that can easily be applied to a variety of industries.
Yes,  I think it's an important aspect of politics. It is also very tailored towards campaign strategy.  Kind professor who is open to feedback
